text: Then Moab rebelled against Israel after the death of Ahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah fell down through a lattice in his upper chamber that was in Samaria and became ill. So he sent messengers and said to them, “Go, inquire of Baal-Zebub the god of Ekron whether I will recover from this illness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel of the Lord said to Elijah the Tishbite, “Arise, go up to meet the messengers of the king of Samaria, and say to them, ‘Is it because there is not a God in Israel, that you go to inquire of Baal-Zebub the god of Ekron?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore thus says the Lord, ‘You will not come down from the bed on which you have gone up but will surely die.’ ” Then Elijah departed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers returned to the king, he said to them, “Why have you returned?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to him, “A man came up to meet us and said to us, ‘Go, return to the king that sent you and say to him: Thus says the Lord: Is it because there is no God in Israel that you are sending to inquire of Baal-Zebub the god of Ekron? Therefore you will not come down from the bed on which you have gone up, but you will surely die.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “What sort of man was he who came up to meet you and told you these things?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They answered him, “He was a hairy man with a leather belt around his waist.”
He said, “It was Elijah the Tishbite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king sent to him a captain of fifty with his fifty men. He went up to Elijah, and there he was, sitting on the top of a hill, and he said to him, “Man of God, the king says, ‘Come down.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elijah answered the captain of fifty: “If I am a man of God, then let fire come down from heaven and consume you and your fifty men.” Then fire came down from heaven and consumed him and his fifty men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the king sent to him another captain of fifty with his fifty men. He said, “Man of God, thus says the king: Come down quickly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah answered them, “If I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven and consume you and your fifty men.” Then the fire of God came down from heaven and consumed him and his fifty men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then again the king sent a third captain of fifty with his fifty men. The third captain of fifty went up, came and fell on his knees before Elijah, and pleaded with him, “Man of God, may my life and the life of these fifty servants of yours be precious in your sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, fire came down from heaven and consumed the two captains of the former fifties with their fifty men. May my life now be precious in your sight.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord said to Elijah, “Go down with him. Do not be afraid of him.” So he arose and went down with him to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Have you sent messengers to inquire of Baal-Zebub the god of Ekron, because there is no God in Israel to inquire of His word? Therefore you will not come down from the bed on which you have gone up, but you will surely die.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he died according to the word of the Lord which Elijah had spoken.
Then Jehoram reigned in his place in the second year of Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, because he had no son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Ahaziah which he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then when the Lord was about to take Elijah up to heaven by a whirlwind, Elijah went with Elisha from Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah said to Elisha, “Tarry here, I ask you, for the Lord has sent me to Bethel.”
But Elisha said to him, “As the Lord lives, and as you live, I will not leave you.” So they went down to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of the prophets who were at Bethel came out to Elisha and said to him, “Do you know that today the Lord is taking away your master from you?”
And he said, “Yes, I know. Keep silent.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah said to him, “Elisha, stay here, for the Lord has sent me to Jericho.”
And he said, “As the Lord lives, and as you live, I will not leave you.” So they entered Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of the prophets who were at Jericho approached Elisha and said to him, “Do you know that today the Lord is taking away your master from you?”
And he said, “Yes, I know. Keep silent.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elijah said to him, “Stay here, for the Lord has sent me to the Jordan.”
And he said, “As the Lord lives, and as you live, I will not leave you.” And the two of them went on.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fifty men of the sons of the prophets went and stood at a distance, and the two of them stood by the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah took his robe and rolled it up and struck the water, and it was divided from one side to the other. Then the two of them crossed on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And as they were crossing, Elijah said to Elisha, “Ask for something, and I will do it for you before I am taken away from you.”
And Elisha said, “Let a double portion of your spirit be upon me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “You have asked for a difficult thing, but if you see me when I am taken from you, it will happen to you. If not, it will not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they continued walking and talking, a chariot of fire and horses of fire separated the two of them, and Elijah went up by a whirlwind into heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha was watching and crying, “My father, my father, the chariot of Israel and its horsemen!” And he did not see him again. Then he grabbed his own clothes and tore them in two pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: He picked up the robe of Elijah that fell from him, and he returned and stood on the bank of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he took the robe of Elijah that fell from him, and struck the water, and said, “Where is the Lord, God of Elijah?” When he had struck the water, it parted from one side to the other, and Elisha crossed over.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sons of the prophets who were at Jericho saw him from far off, they said, “The spirit of Elijah rests on Elisha.” And they came to meet him and bowed down to the ground before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to him, “Look now, there are fifty strong men with your servants. Let them go and look for your master. Perhaps the Spirit of the Lord has lifted him up and thrown him on some mountain or into some valley.”
He said, “Do not send them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they urged him until he was ashamed, he said, “Send them.” So they sent fifty men, and they searched for three days but did not find him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they returned to him (for he had stayed at Jericho), he said to them, “Did I not say to you, do not go?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the men of the city said to Elisha, “The location of this city is good, as my lord sees, but the water is bad, and the land is unfruitful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Bring me a new bowl and put salt in it.” So they brought it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went out to the spring of water and threw the salt into it and said, “Thus says the Lord: I have healed this water. No more death or unfruitfulness will come from it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the waters have been healthy until this day, according to the word that Elisha spoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went up from there to Bethel, and going up on the way, little boys came out of the city and made fun of him and said to him, “Go up, you bald head! Go up, you bald head!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He turned around, saw them, and cursed them in the name of the Lord. Then two she-bears came out of the woods and ripped open forty-two of the boys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went from there to Mount Carmel, and from there he returned to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jehoram son of Ahab reigned over Israel in Samaria in the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah and reigned twelve years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, but not like his father and mother, for he removed the pillar of Baal that his father had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless he clung to the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who had caused Israel to sin. He did not depart from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Mesha king of Moab was a sheep-breeder and gave back to the king of Israel a hundred thousand lambs and the wool of a hundred thousand rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Ahab died, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Jehoram went out of Samaria at that time and mustered all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He went and sent to Jehoshaphat the king of Judah, saying, “The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you go with me to Moab to battle?”
He said, “I will go up. I am as you are, my people as your people, and my horses as your horses.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said, “Which way should we go up?”
And he said, “The way through the Wilderness of Edom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel, the king of Judah, and the king of Edom went, and they marched around seven days. But there was no water for the camp or for the livestock that followed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said, “Alas! The Lord has called these three kings to give them into the hand of Moab!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Jehoshaphat said, “Is there a prophet of the Lord here, through whom we may inquire of the Lord?”
Then one of the king of Israel’s servants answered, “Elisha the son of Shaphat, who poured water on the hands of Elijah, is here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat said, “The word of the Lord is with him.” So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat and the king of Edom went down to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha said to the king of Israel, “What have I to do with you? Go to your father’s prophets, or to your mother’s prophets.”
Then the king of Israel said to him, “No. The Lord has called these three kings to deliver them into the hand of Moab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said, “As the Lord of Hosts lives, before whom I stand, surely, were it not for my regard for Jehoshaphat the king of Judah, I would not look at you nor see you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now bring me a musician.”
And when the musician played, the hand of the Lord came upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Thus says the Lord, ‘Make this valley full of pools.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For thus says the Lord, ‘You will not see wind, nor will you see rain, yet that valley will be filled with water, that you may drink, both you and your livestock, and your cattle.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This is an easy thing in the sight of the Lord, and He will give the Moabites into your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will strike every fortified city and every choice city, and will cut down every good tree, and stop every spring of water, and you will ruin every good piece of land with stones.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So in the morning as the offering was offered up, suddenly water flowed from the way of Edom, and the land was filled with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the Moabites heard that the kings had come up to fight against them, all who were able to bear arms and older were summoned and stood at the border.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up early in the morning, and the sun shone on the water, and the Moabites saw the water opposite them was as red as blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “This is blood. The kings have surely fought together; and they have killed one another. Now therefore, Moab, to the spoil!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the camp of Israel, the children of Israel arose and struck the Moabites, so that they ran from them. And they went forward into their land, killing the Moabites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They demolished the cities, and on every good piece of land every man threw a stone and filled it with stones, and they stopped every spring of water and cut down every good tree. Only in Kir Hareseth did the stones in the wall remain, until the slingers surrounded it and struck it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Moab saw that the battle was overwhelming him, he took with him seven hundred swordsmen to break through to the king of Edom, but they were unable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took his firstborn son, who would have reigned in his place, and offered him for a burnt offering on the wall. And great wrath came upon Israel, and they departed from him and returned to their own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now one of the wives of the sons of the prophets cried to Elisha, “Your servant my husband is dead, and you know that your servant feared the Lord, but a creditor has come to take my two sons as slaves.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha said to her, “What shall I do for you? Tell me, what do you have in the house?”
She said, “Your servant has nothing in the house except a jar of oil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Go, ask for vessels from all your neighbors, empty vessels and not just a few.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go in, shut the door behind you and your sons, and pour the oil into all these vessels. When each is full, set it aside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she left him and shut the door behind her and her sons, and they kept bringing vessels to her, and she kept pouring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the vessels were full, she said to her son, “Bring me another vessel.”
But he said to her, “There is not another vessel.” And the oil ceased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she went and told the man of God. And he said, “Go, sell the oil, and pay your debt, and you and your children can live on the rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Elisha passed through Shunem, and a noble woman was there who urged him to eat a meal. So whenever he passed through, he stopped there to eat a meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to her husband, “I know that he is a holy man of God regularly passing through near us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us make a little walled upper room and put for him there a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp, so when he comes to us he can stay there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day he came by there, and he turned aside to the upper room and lay down.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Gehazi his servant, “Call this Shunammite woman.” So he called her and she stood before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to him, “Say to her, Look, you have gone to all this trouble for us. What may be done for you? Would you have a word spoken on your behalf to the king, or to the captain of the army?”
And she answered, “I am living among my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “What may be done for her?”
And Gehazi said, “Actually, she has no son, and her husband is old.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Call her.” When he had called her, she stood in the entrance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “At this season, when it is time, you will embrace a son.”
And she said, “No, my lord, man of God, do not lie to your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman conceived and bore a son at that season, at the time that Elisha had told her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the child was older, he went out one day to his father with the reapers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to his father, “My head, my head!”
And he said to a servant, “Carry him to his mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had taken him and brought him to his mother, the boy sat on her knees until noon, and died.
speaker: Narrator

text: She went up, and laid him down on the bed of the man of God, shut the door on him, and went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she called to her husband, “Send me one of the servants and one of the donkeys, so that I may run to the man of God and return.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “Why are you going to him today? It is neither New Moon nor Sabbath.”
She said, “It will be all right.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she saddled the donkey and said to her servant, “Lead on, and do not hold back for me unless I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So she went and came to the man of God at Mount Carmel.
And when the man of God saw her far off, he said to Gehazi his servant, “Look, over there is the Shunammite woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now run to meet her, and say to her, Are you all right? Is your husband all right? Is the child all right?”
And she said, “It is all right.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When she came to the man of God at the mountain, she grabbed his feet. Gehazi approached to push her away. But the man of God said, “Let her alone, for she is in bitter distress, and the Lord has hidden it from me and has not told me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said, “Did I ask for a son from my lord? Did I not say, Do not give me false hope?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to Gehazi, “Prepare yourself, take my staff in your hand, and go. If you find anyone, do not greet him, and if anyone greets you, do not answer him, and lay my staff on the face of the boy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the boy’s mother said, “As the Lord lives, and as you live, I will not leave without you.” And he got up and followed her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gehazi passed through ahead of them and laid the staff on the face of the boy, but there was no sound or response. So he returned to meet him and told him, “The boy is not awake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha came into the house, he saw that the boy was dead, lying on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went in, and shut the door on the two of them, and prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went up and lay on the child, put his face on his face, and his eyes on his eyes, and his hands on his hands. Then he bent over the child, and the child’s flesh warmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he got down, walked once back and forth in the house, and went up, and bent over him; the boy sneezed seven times, and the boy opened his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha called Gehazi and said, “Call the Shunammite woman.” So he called her, and she came to him. Then he said, “Pick up your son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she came in, fell at his feet, and bowed down to the ground. Then she picked up her son and went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha returned to Gilgal, there was a famine in the land. The sons of the prophets were sitting before him, and he said to his servant, “Put on the big cooking pot, and boil some stew for the sons of the prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One went out into the field to gather herbs. He found a wild vine and gathered from it wild gourds, filling his clothes, and came and split them into the pot of stew, but they did not recognize them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they poured it out for the men to eat. But as they were eating the stew, they cried out, “Man of God, there is death in the pot.” They could not eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “Then bring flour.” He threw it into the pot and said, “Pour it for the people and let them eat.” And there was nothing bad in the pot.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man came from Baal Shalishah, and he brought the man of God food from the first fruits—twenty loaves of barley and fresh ears of grain—in his sack. And Elisha said, “Give it to the people and let them eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But his servant said, “How can I set this before a hundred men?”
He said, “Give it to the people and let them eat, for thus says the Lord, ‘They will eat and have some left.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he set it before them, they ate, and some was left over, according to the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Naaman, captain of the army of the king of Aram, was a great man before his master and held favor because by him the Lord had given deliverance to Aram. He was also a mighty warrior, but he had leprosy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Arameans had gone out raiding and had taken captive a little girl from the land of Israel, and she waited on the wife of Naaman.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to her mistress, “If only my lord were before the prophet who is in Samaria! Then he would take away his leprosy from him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Naaman went in and told his lord, “Thus and so spoke the girl from the land of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Aram said, “Go, and I will send a letter to the king of Israel.” So he went and took with him ten talents of silver, six thousand shekels of gold, and ten sets of clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the letter to the king of Israel, which read, “Now when this letter comes to you, know that I have sent Naaman my servant to you, that you may take away from him his leprosy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel had read the letter, he tore his clothes and said, “Am I God, to kill and to give life, that this man sends a man to me to take away his leprosy? But consider, and see how he is seeking a quarrel with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Elisha the man of God heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent word to the king, saying, “Why have you torn your clothes? Let him come to me, and he will know that there is a prophet in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Naaman came with his horses and chariot and stood at the entrance to the house of Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha sent a messenger to him, saying, “Go and wash seven times in the Jordan, and your flesh will be returned and cleansed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Naaman became angry and went away and said to himself, “Surely he could have come out, and stood and called on the name of the Lord his God, and waved his hand over the infected area, and taken away the leprosy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are not Abana and Pharpar, rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? Could I not wash in them and be clean?” So he turned and went away in a rage.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his servants approached and spoke to him, “My father, if the prophet had told you to do some great thing, would you not have done it? How much more when he said to you, ‘Wash and be clean’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went down and dipped himself in the Jordan seven times, according to the word of the man of God, and his flesh returned like the flesh of a little boy, and he was clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he returned to the man of God, he and all his company. He came and stood before him, and he said, “Now I know that there is no God in all the land, except in Israel. Now take a gift from your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “As the Lord lives, before whom I stand, I will take no gift.” He urged him to take it, but he refused.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Naaman said, “If not, let two mule loads of dirt be given to your servant, for your servant will no longer offer a burnt offering or sacrifice to any god, except the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But may the Lord pardon your servant on one account: When my master enters the house of Rimmon to worship, and he leans on my hand, and I bow down in the house of Rimmon, when I do bow down in the house of Rimmon, may the Lord pardon your servant on this one account.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Go in peace.” So he departed from him a short distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gehazi the servant of Elisha the man of God said, “My master has spared Naaman the Aramean by not taking from his hands what he brought. As the Lord lives, I will run after him and take something from him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gehazi pursued Naaman. Then Naaman saw him running after him, jumped down from the chariot to meet him, and said, “Is everything all right?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Everything is all right. My master has sent me and says, ‘Even now two servants from Ephraim, from the sons of the prophets, have come to me. Give them a talent of silver and two changes of clothes.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman said, “Please, take two talents.” He urged him and tied up two talents of silver in two bags with two changes of clothes and gave them to two of his servants, who carried them before Gehazi.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came to Ophel, he took them from their hand and put them away in the house. Then he sent the men away, and they departed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he entered and stood before his master. And Elisha said to him, “Where have you come from, Gehazi?”
And he said, “Your servant went here and there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Did my heart not go with you when the man turned from his chariot to meet you? Is it a time to take money, and to take garments, olives and vineyards, sheep and oxen, male and female servants?
speaker: Narrator

text: The leprosy of Naaman will cling to you and to your descendants forever.” So he went out from his presence, leprous like snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the sons of the prophets said to Elisha, “Look, the place where we are living with you is too small for us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us go to the Jordan and take from there one beam per man, and let us make for ourselves a place to live there.”
And Elisha said, “Go.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then one of them said, “Please come with your servants.”
And he said, “I will come.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he went with them.
And they came to the Jordan and cut down trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as one was cutting down a tree, the axe head fell into the water. He cried, “Ah, master! It was borrowed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man of God said, “Where did it fall?” When he showed him the place, he cut off a stick, and threw it in there, and he made the iron float.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elisha said, “Pick it up.” And he reached out his hand and took it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Aram was fighting against Israel, and he took counsel with his servants, saying, “At such and such a place will be my camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man of God sent word to the king of Israel, saying, “Take care not to pass through this place, for the Arameans are marching down there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel sent word to the place of which the man of God spoke. He warned him and was on his guard there more than once.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mind of the king of Aram was troubled by this, so he called his servants and said to them, “Will you not tell me who among us sides with the king of Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of his servants said, “No one, my lord, O king. Elisha, the prophet who is in Israel, tells the king of Israel the words that you speak in your bedroom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Go and see where he is, so that I may send for him and take him.” And it was told to him, “He is in Dothan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent horses, chariots, and a great army there. They came by night and surrounded the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a servant of the man of God rose early in the morning and went out, a force surrounded the city both with horses and chariots. And his servant said to him, “Alas, my master! What will we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Do not be afraid, for there are more with us than with them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha prayed, “Lord, open his eyes and let him see.” So the Lord opened the eyes of the young man, and he saw that the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire surrounding Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came down to him, Elisha prayed to the Lord, “Strike this people with blindness.” And He struck them with blindness according to the word of Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said to them, “This is not the way, and this is not the city. Follow me, and let me bring you to the man whom you seek.” But he led them to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they entered Samaria, Elisha said, “Lord, open the eyes of these men and let them see.” And the Lord opened their eyes, and they saw that they were in the middle of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Elisha when he saw them, “My father, shall I kill them? Shall I kill them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “You shall not kill them. Did you capture with your sword and with your bow those whom you want to kill? Set bread and water before them, and let them eat and drink and then go to their master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he prepared for them a great banquet. When they had eaten and had drunk, he sent them away, and they went to their master. So the Aramean raiders did not enter into the land of Israel again.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Ben-Hadad king of Aram gathered all his army, went up, and besieged Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a great famine in Samaria, and they besieged it until a donkey’s head was sold for eighty shekels of silver, and one-fourth of a kab of dove droppings for five shekels of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the king of Israel was walking across the city wall, a woman cried out to him, “Help, my lord king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “If the Lord will not help you, how can I help you? From the threshing floor or from the winepress?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the king said to her, “What is wrong with you?”
And she said, “This woman said to me, ‘Give your son and let us eat him today, and we will eat my son tomorrow.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So we boiled my son and ate him. The next day I said to her, ‘Give your son, that we may eat him.’ But she has hidden her son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard the words of the woman, he tore his clothes. And since he was walking across the city wall, the people saw that he had sackcloth on his body underneath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “So may God do to me, and even more, if the head of Elisha the son of Shaphat stands on his shoulders after today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. The king sent a messenger, but before the messenger came to him, Elisha said to the elders, “Are you aware that this son of a murderer has sent a man to take off my head? When the messenger enters, shut the door and hold it against him. Is not the sound of his master’s feet behind him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And while he was speaking with them, the messenger came down to him, and then the king said, “This calamity is of the Lord! Why should I hope in the Lord any longer?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said, “Hear the word of the Lord: Thus says the Lord: Tomorrow about this time a measure of fine flour will be sold for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel, at the gate of Samaria.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then an officer on whose hand the king leaned answered the man of God, “If the Lord were to make windows in heaven, could this thing happen?”
And he said, “You will see it with your eyes, but you will not eat from it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: There were four leprous men at the entry of the gate, and they said to one another, “Why are we sitting here until we die?
speaker: Narrator

text: If we say, ‘Let us enter the city,’ the famine is in the city, and we shall die there. But if we sit here, we die also. Now come, let us fall into the camp of the Arameans. If they spare our lives, we will live, and if they kill us, we will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they rose at twilight to enter the camp of the Arameans. When they came to the edge of the camp of the Arameans, there was no one there.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had caused the Aramean camp to hear the sound of chariots, horses, even the sound of a large army, so that they said to one another, “Listen, the king of Israel has hired the kings of the Hittites and the kings of the Egyptians to come against us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they got up and ran away in the twilight and abandoned their tents, their horses, and their donkeys. The camp remained just as it was, and they ran for their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: When these leprous men came to the edge of the camp, they went into one tent. They ate and drank, carried off silver, gold, and clothes, and went and hid them. Then they went back, entered another tent, and carried off things from there and went and hid them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said to one another, “We are not doing right today. This is a day of good news. If we are silent and wait until the morning light, we will be found guilty. Let us go now and enter the city and tell the king’s household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went and called to the gatekeepers of the city, and they told them, “We came to the camp of the Arameans, and there was no one there. There was no sound of a man’s voice, only horses tied, donkeys tied, and the tents as they were.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the gatekeepers called out and told the king’s household inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king got up in the night and said to his servants, “I will show you what the Arameans have done to us. They know that we are starving, so they left the camp to hide themselves in the field, saying, ‘When they come out of the city, we will capture them alive and get into the city.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of his servants answered, “Let some men take five of the remaining horses, since those remaining will suffer the fate of the whole multitude of Israel that have perished already; so let us send them and see.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took two chariots with horses, and the king sent them after the army of the Arameans, saying, “Go and see.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went after them to the Jordan, and the whole way was full of clothes and vessels, which the Arameans had thrown away in their haste. Then the messengers returned and told the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people went out and looted the camp of the Arameans. So a measure of fine flour was sold for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel, according to the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king had appointed the officer on whose hand he leaned to have charge over the gate, and the people trampled him in the gate, and he died, just as the man of God had said when the king came down to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man of God had spoken to the king, saying, “Two seahs of barley shall be sold for a shekel, and a seah of fine flour for a shekel, about this time tomorrow at the gate of Samaria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The officer had answered the man of God, “If the Lord should make windows in heaven, could such a thing happen?” And he had said, “You shall see it with your own eyes, but you shall not eat of it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So it happened to him, for the people trampled him in the gate, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha spoke to the woman whose son he had restored to life, “Get up and go, you and your household, and sojourn wherever you can, for the Lord has called for a famine, and it will come on the land for seven years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the woman got up and did according to the word of the man of God. She went with her household and sojourned in the land of the Philistines for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of seven years, the woman returned from the land of the Philistines, and she went forth to appeal to the king for her house and her field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king was talking with Gehazi the servant of the man of God, saying, “Tell me all the great things that Elisha has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As he was telling the king how he had restored a dead body to life, the woman whose son he had restored to life started appealing to the king for her house and her land.
Gehazi said, “My lord king, this is the woman, and this is her son whom Elisha restored to life.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the king questioned the woman, she told him.
So the king appointed to her an official, saying, “Restore all that was hers and all the proceeds of the field from the day that she abandoned the land until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha came to Damascus while Ben-Hadad the king of Aram was ill, and he was told, “The man of God has come here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Hazael, “Take a present with you and go to meet the man of God. Inquire of the Lord through him, saying, ‘Will I recover from this illness?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hazael went to meet him and took a present with him, all sorts of good things from Damascus, forty camel loads. He came and stood before him and said, “Your son Ben-Hadad king of Aram has sent me to you, asking, ‘Will I recover from this illness?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elisha said to him, “Go, say to him, ‘You will certainly recover,’ but the Lord has shown me that he will certainly die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazael stared at him until he was ashamed. Then the man of God wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hazael said, “Why are you weeping, my lord?”
He said, “Because I know the evil that you will do to the children of Israel. You will set their fortresses on fire. You will kill their young men with the sword. You will smash their children and rip open their pregnant women.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hazael said, “What? Is your servant a dog that he should do this great thing?”
And Elisha said, “The Lord has shown me that you will be king over Aram.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he left Elisha and went to his master, who said to him, “What did Elisha say to you?” And he said, “He told me that you would surely recover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the next day he took a blanket, dipped it in water, and spread it on his face, so that he died. And Hazael reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth year of Joram the son of Ahab, king of Israel, Jehoram the son of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned eight years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in the way of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Ahab had done, for the daughter of Ahab was his wife. He did evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the Lord was not willing to destroy Judah, for the sake of His servant David, since He promised to give a lamp to him and his sons perpetually.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his days Edom rebelled against the rule of Judah, and they put a king over themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoram crossed over to Zair, all his chariots with him, and he rose at night and struck Edom and the captains of their chariots who had surrounded him. But the people fled to their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Edom has been in rebellion against the rule of Judah until this day. Libnah rebelled at the same time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the deeds of Jehoram and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoram slept with his fathers and was buried with his fathers in the City of David. Ahaziah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year of Joram the son of Ahab, king of Israel, Ahaziah the son of Jehoram, king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king. He reigned one year in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Athaliah, the daughter of Omri, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in the way of the house of Ahab and did evil in the sight of the Lord, as the house of Ahab did, for he was the son-in-law of the house of Ahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went with Joram the son of Ahab to the war against Hazael king of Aram at Ramoth Gilead, and the Arameans struck Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text:
King Joram returned to be healed in Jezreel of the wounds which the Arameans had inflicted on him at Ramah when he fought against Hazael king of Aram.
And Ahaziah the son of Jehoram, king of Judah, went down to see Joram the son of Ahab in Jezreel because he was ill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha the prophet called one of the sons of the prophets, “Prepare yourself. Take this flask of oil in your hand, and go to Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you get there, look for Jehu the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi. Go in and make him rise from among his brothers, and bring him into an inner chamber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take the flask of oil, pour it on his head, and say, ‘Thus says the Lord: I have anointed you king over Israel.’ Then open the door and flee. Do not wait.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the young man, the prophet, went to Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he arrived, the commanders of the army were sitting, and he said, “I have a word for you, Commander.”
Jehu said, “Which one of us?”
And he said, “For you, Commander.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he arose, went into the house, poured the oil on his head, and said to him, “Thus says the Lord, God of Israel: I am anointing you king over the people of the Lord, over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will strike the house of Ahab your master, and I will avenge the blood of my servants the prophets and the blood of all the servants of the Lord from the hand of Jezebel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole house of Ahab will perish, and I will cut off from Ahab all the males in Israel, both imprisoned and free.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the house of Ahab like the house of Jeroboam son of Nebat and like the house of Baasha the son of Ahijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dogs will eat Jezebel in the territory of Jezreel, and no one will bury her.” Then he opened the door and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Jehu had returned to his master’s servants, one said to him, “Is all well? Why did this madman come to you?”
And he said to them, “You know this man and his babble.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said, “A lie! Tell us.”
Then he said, “Thus and thus he spoke to me, saying, ‘Thus says the Lord: I am anointing you king over Israel.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they hurried. Each took his clothes, put them under him on the bare stairs, and blew a horn, saying, “Jehu is king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi, conspired against Joram. Joram had been guarding Ramoth Gilead, he and all Israel, because of Hazael king of Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Joram had returned to be healed in Jezreel from the wounds with which the Arameans had stricken him when he fought with Hazael king of Aram. So Jehu said, “If this be your minds, let no fugitive exit the city to go tell Jezreel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu rode in a chariot and went to Jezreel, for Joram lay there. Ahaziah king of Judah had come down to see Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A watchman was standing on the tower in Jezreel, and he saw the company of Jehu as he was coming and said, “I see a company.”
And Joram said, “Take a horseman and send him to meet them, and let him say, ‘Is it peace?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the horseman went to meet him and said, “Thus says the king, ‘Is it peace?’ ”
But Jehu said, “What have you to do with peace? Circle in behind me.”
So the watchman reported, “The messenger came to them, but he is not returning.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he sent out a second horseman, who came to them and said, “Thus says the king, ‘Is it peace?’ ”
Again, Jehu said, “What have you to do with peace? Circle in behind me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchman reported, “He came to them, but he is not returning. The driving is like the driving of Jehu the son of Nimshi, for he drives furiously.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joram said, “Hitch my chariot.” So his chariot was hitched, and Joram king of Israel and Ahaziah king of Judah went out, each in his chariot. They went out to meet Jehu and found him on the property of Naboth the Jezreelite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Joram saw Jehu he said, “Is it peace, Jehu?”
And he said, “What peace, so long as the harlotries of your mother Jezebel and her sorceries are so many?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joram turned the reins, fled, and said to Ahaziah, “There is treachery, Ahaziah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu drew a bow with his full strength and shot Joram between his shoulder blades. The arrow went out at his heart, and he kneeled down in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu said to Bidkar his officer, “Lift him up and throw him on the property of the field of Naboth the Jezreelite. Remember when you and I were riding together after Ahab his father and the Lord pronounced this oracle about him:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Surely I have seen yesterday the blood of Naboth and his sons, declares the Lord, and I will pay you back on this property, declares the Lord.’ Now lift him up and throw him onto the property, according to the word of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Ahaziah the king of Judah saw this, he fled on the path to the garden house. Jehu chased after him and said, “Shoot him too.” So they shot him on the ascent to Gur, which is by Ibleam. And he fled to Megiddo and died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants carried him in a chariot to Jerusalem and buried him in his tomb with his fathers in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eleventh year of Joram the son of Ahab, Ahaziah became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu came to Jezreel, Jezebel heard about it. She put black paint on her eyes, adorned her head, and looked down through the window.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jehu entered in at the gate, she said, “Is everything all right, Zimri, murderer of his master?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he lifted up his face toward the window and said, “Who is on my side? Who?” And two or three eunuchs looked down to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Drop her down.” So they dropped her down and some of her blood splattered on the wall and on the horses. Then he trampled her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he entered, ate and drank, and said, “Attend to that cursed woman and bury her, for she is a king’s daughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went to bury her, but they found nothing of her except a skull, the feet, and the palms of her hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: They returned and told Jehu, and he said, “This is the word of the Lord, which He spoke by His servant Elijah the Tishbite, saying, ‘On the property of Jezreel dogs will eat the flesh of Jezebel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The corpse of Jezebel will be like dung in the field on the property of Jezreel, so that they cannot say, This is Jezebel.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ahab had seventy sons in Samaria. So Jehu wrote letters and sent them to Samaria to the captains of Jezreel, to the elders, and to the guardians of the sons of Ahab, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now as soon as this letter comes to you—since you are with your master’s sons, chariots, horses, a fortified city, and weapons—
speaker: Narrator

text: select the best and most fitting of your master’s sons, put him on his father’s throne, and fight for your master’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they were extremely afraid and said, “Two kings could not stand before him. How can we stand?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he who was over the house, and he who was over the city, the elders, and the guardians sent word to Jehu, saying, “We are your servants, and everything you say to us we will do. We will not appoint a man king. Do what is good in your eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he wrote a second letter to them, saying, “If you belong to me and will obey me, take the heads of your master’s sons and come to me at Jezreel at this time tomorrow.”
Now the king’s sons, seventy men, were with the great men of the city who brought them up.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the letter came to them, they took the king’s sons, slaughtered all seventy, put their heads in baskets, and sent them to him in Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the messenger came and told him, saying, “They have brought the heads of the king’s sons.”
Then he said, “Put them in two heaps at the entry of the gate until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When morning came, he went out and stood and said to all the people, “You are innocent. I conspired against my master and killed him, but who struck all these?
speaker: Narrator

text: Know then that the words of the Lord which He spoke about the house of Ahab will not fall to the ground. The Lord has done that which He spoke by His servant Elijah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu struck all that remained of the house of Ahab in Jezreel and all his great men, his confidants, and his priests, until he left him no survivor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he got up and went to Samaria. When he was at Beth Eked of the Shepherds on the way,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jehu found the brothers of Ahaziah king of Judah and said, “Who are you?”
And they said, “We are brothers of Ahaziah, and we have come down to visit the sons of the king and the sons of the queen mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Capture them alive.” So they took them alive and slaughtered them at the pit of Beth Eked, forty-two men. Not a man of them remained.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he left there and found Jehonadab son of Rekab coming to meet him. He greeted him and said to him, “Is your heart right with me, as my heart is with yours?”
And Jehonadab said, “It is.”
“If it is, give me your hand.” So he gave him his hand, and he pulled him up to him into the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Come with me, and see my zeal for the Lord.” So he made him ride in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he came to Samaria and struck all that remained to Ahab in Samaria until he exterminated them, according to the word of the Lord which He spoke to Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu gathered all the people and said to them, “Ahab served Baal a little, but Jehu will serve him much.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now call to me all the prophets of Baal, all his worshippers, and all his priests. Let none go unaccounted for, because I have a great sacrifice for Baal. All who are not accounted for will not live.” But Jehu did it with cunning in order to destroy the servants of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu said, “Sanctify a festive assembly for Baal.” So they proclaimed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu sent word through all Israel, and all the worshippers of Baal came. Not a man remained who did not come. They came into the house of Baal, and the house of Baal was full from one end to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the one in charge of the wardrobe, “Bring out garments for all the worshippers of Baal.” So he brought them garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu and Jehonadab the son of Rekab went into the house of Baal and said to the worshippers of Baal, “Search and see that there are no worshippers of the Lord here with you and only worshippers of Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went to offer sacrifices and burnt offerings, but Jehu put eighty men outside and said, “If any of the men whom I have brought into your hands escapes, the one who lets him go will die in his place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he had finished making the burnt offering, Jehu said to the guards and the officers, “Go in. Kill them. No one comes out.” So they struck them with the edge of the sword. The guards and the officers threw them out and went to the city of the house of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought out the sacred pillar from the house of Baal and burned it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They broke down the sacred pillar of Baal, and tore down the house of Baal and made it a latrine to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu exterminated Baal from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin, Jehu did not turn aside (that is, the golden calves that were in Bethel and Dan).
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Jehu, “Because you have done well by doing what is right in My sight, and have done to the house of Ahab all that was in My heart, four generations of your sons will sit on the throne of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehu was not careful to walk in the law of the Lord God of Israel with all his heart. He did not turn aside from the sins of Jeroboam, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days the Lord began to trim off parts of Israel, and Hazael struck them in all the territory of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text: from the Jordan eastward, all the land of Gilead, the Gadites, the Reubenites, the Manassites from Aroer, which is by the River Arnon, even Gilead and Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jehu, all he did and all his power, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu slept with his fathers, and they buried him in Samaria. Jehoahaz his son became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The days that Jehu reigned over Israel in Samaria were twenty-eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Athaliah the mother of Ahaziah saw that her son was dead, she rose up and destroyed all the royal descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehosheba, the daughter of King Joram, sister of Ahaziah, took Joash the son of Ahaziah, and stole him away from among the king’s sons who were being murdered; and they hid him and his nurse in the bedroom, from Athaliah, so that he was not killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was with her, hidden in the house of the Lord for six years, while Athaliah reigned over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the seventh year Jehoiada sent word and took the captains of hundreds from the Carites and the guards and brought them to him in the house of the Lord. He made a covenant with them, put them under oath in the house of the Lord, and then showed them the king’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He commanded them, saying, “This is the thing that you shall do: One-third of your unit, those who come on duty on the Sabbath, will guard the king’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: One-third will be at the gate of Sur, and one-third will be at the gate behind the guards. You will take turns guarding the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two of your companies from all who go out on the Sabbath will keep watch over the house of the Lord for the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will encircle the king, each man with his weapons in his hand, and the one that comes within the ranks must be killed. They must be with the king when he goes out and comes in.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The captains of hundreds did according to everything that Jehoiada the priest commanded. Each took his men, those who came on duty on the Sabbath, with those that went off duty on the Sabbath, and came to Jehoiada the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the priest gave to the captains of hundreds spears and shields which belonged to King David that were in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The guards stood, each with his weapons in his hand, from the south side of the house to the north side of the house, along the altar and the house, surrounding the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought out the king’s son and put the crown on him and gave him the testimony. They made him king and anointed him. Then they clapped their hands and said, “Live, O king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Athaliah heard the sound of the guards and the people, so she came to the people in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she looked, and the king was standing by a pillar according to custom, the captains and the trumpeters by the king, and all the people of the land were rejoicing and blowing trumpets. So Athaliah tore her clothes and cried, “Conspiracy, conspiracy!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoiada the priest commanded the captains of hundreds, those appointed over the forces, “Bring her out of the house to the ranks, and kill with the sword whoever follows her.” For the priest had said, “Let her not be killed in the house of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they laid hands on her, and she came through the horses’ entrance into the king’s house. Then she was put to death there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada made a covenant between the Lord and the king and the people, that they should be the people of the Lord, and also between the king and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then all the people of the land entered the house of Baal and broke down its altars. His images they thoroughly broke in pieces, and they killed Mattan the priest of Baal before the altars.
The priest put appointees over the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the captains of hundreds, the Carites, the guards, and all the people of the land. Then they brought down the king from the house of the Lord and marched through the gate of the guards to the king’s house. Then he sat on the throne of the kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of the land rejoiced, and the city was quiet. They had killed Athaliah with the sword at the king’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash was seven years old when he became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year of Jehu, Jehoash became king. He reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zibiah of Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash did what was right in the sight of the Lord all his days because Jehoiada the priest instructed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the high places were not taken away. The people still sacrificed and made offerings in the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jehoash said to the priests, “All the consecrated money that is brought into the house of the Lord, the money for which each man is currently assessed, and all the money that is brought voluntarily to the house of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: let the priests receive it, each from his donor, and repair the damages to the house wherever damages are found.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the twenty-third year of King Jehoash the priests had not repaired the damages to the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Jehoash called for Jehoiada the priest and the other priests and said to them, “Why have you not repaired the damages to the house? So now money will no longer be taken from your donors. You will give it over for the damages to the house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests agreed that they should take no more money from the people, nor repair the damages of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoiada the priest took a chest, made a hole in its lid, and set it beside the altar on the right side as one enters the house of the Lord. The priests guarding the threshold put there all the money that was brought into the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever they saw that there was much money in the chest, the king’s scribe and the high priest went up, emptied it, and counted the money that was found in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave the money that was weighed out into the hands of the workers who were appointed to the house of the Lord. Then they paid it out to the carpenters and builders working on the house of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: to the masons and stonecutters, and to buy timber and cut stone to repair the damages to the house of the Lord, that is, whatever went out for repairs to the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for the house of the Lord silver bowls, snuffers, sprinkling basins, trumpets, and all the gold and silver vessels were not made with any of the money that was brought into the house of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: for they gave it to the workmen, and they repaired the house of the Lord with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not settle accounts with the men in whose hand they gave the money to give to the workmen, for they dealt faithfully.
speaker: Narrator

text: The money from the guilt offerings and the money from the sin offerings were not brought into the house of the Lord. It belonged to the priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hazael king of Aram went up, fought against Gath, and seized it. Then Hazael set his face to go up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoash king of Judah took all the consecrated things that Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, his fathers, kings of Judah, had dedicated and his own consecrated things, all the gold that was found in the treasures of the house of the Lord and in the king’s house, and sent it to Hazael king of Aram. Then Hazael went away from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Joash, and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants rose up, made a conspiracy, and struck Joash in the house of Millo, which goes down to Silla.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jozabad the son of Shimeath and Jehozabad the son of Shomer, his servants, struck him, and he died. They buried him with his fathers in the City of David. Then Amaziah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-third year of Joash the son of Ahaziah, king of Judah, Jehoahaz the son of Jehu reigned over Israel in Samaria for seventeen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord and followed the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin. He did not turn aside from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord was kindled against Israel, so He gave them into the hand of Hazael king of Aram and into the hand of Ben-Hadad the son of Hazael all their days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoahaz appeased the Lord, and the Lord listened to him. For He saw the oppression of Israel, because the king of Aram oppressed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord gave Israel a savior, so that they got out from under the hand of Aram. Then the children of Israel dwelt in their tents as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, they did not turn aside from the sins of the house of Jeroboam, who caused Israel to sin, but walked in them. The Asherah pole also stood in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoahaz had only fifty horsemen, ten chariots, and ten thousand footmen left, for the king of Aram had destroyed them and made them like the dust at threshing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jehoahaz, all that he did and his power, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehoahaz slept with his fathers, and they buried him in Samaria. Joash his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-seventh year of Joash king of Judah, Jehoash the son of Jehoahaz reigned over Israel in Samaria for sixteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not turn aside from all the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin, but he walked in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the deeds of Joash, all that he did and his power with which he fought against Amaziah king of Judah, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joash slept with his fathers, and Jeroboam sat on his throne. Joash was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha had become sick with the illness of which he would die. So Joash the king of Israel went down to him and wept before him, and said, “My father, my father, the chariot of Israel and its horsemen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said to him, “Take a bow and arrows.” So he took a bow and arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to the king of Israel, “Draw the bow.” So he drew it. Elisha put his hands on the king’s hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Open the east window.” So he opened it. Then Elisha said, “Shoot.” So he shot. Then he said, “The arrow of the deliverance of the Lord, and the arrow of deliverance from Aram; for you must strike Aram in Aphek until you have destroyed them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Take the arrows.” So he took them. Then he said to the king of Israel, “Strike the ground.” So he struck it three times and stood there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man of God was angry with him and said, “You should have struck it five or six times. Then you would have stricken Aram until you had finished them. Now you will strike Aram just three times.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Elisha died, and they buried him.
Now Moabite raiders would enter the land in the spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were burying a man, they saw raiders. So they threw the man into the tomb of Elisha. When the man touched the bones of Elisha, he came to life and stood on his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Hazael king of Aram oppressed Israel all the days of Jehoahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was gracious to them and had compassion on them. He turned toward them because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and would not yet destroy them or cast them from His presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hazael king of Aram died and Ben-Hadad his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehoash the son of Jehoahaz took back the cities from Ben-Hadad the son of Hazael that had been taken from Jehoahaz his father in war. Three times Joash struck him and recovered the cities of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year of Joash son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel, Amaziah the son of Joash, king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king and reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jehoaddan from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the sight of the Lord, only not like David his father. He did everything that Joash his father did.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not remove the high places. Still the people sacrificed and made offerings on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he seized the kingdom, he killed his servants who had killed his father, the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not kill the children of the murderers, according to what is written in the Book of the Law of Moses, in which the Lord commanded, “Fathers must not be put to death for the children, nor the children be put to death for the fathers. Rather, a man should be put to death for his own sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck ten thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt and captured Sela in battle. He called it Joktheel, as it is to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, son of Jehu, king of Israel, saying, “Come, let us look one another in the face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoash the king of Israel sent word to Amaziah king of Judah, saying, “The thorn bush in Lebanon sent to the cedar in Lebanon, saying, ‘Give your daughter to my son for a wife.’ But a wild animal passed through in Lebanon and trampled the thorn bush.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have indeed struck Edom, and your heart has lifted you up. Enjoy respect and sit at home. Why stir up trouble and fall, you and Judah with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amaziah would not listen. So Jehoash king of Israel went up, and he and Amaziah king of Judah looked one another in the face at Beth Shemesh, which belongs to Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah was beaten before Israel, and every man fled to his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash king of Israel captured Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Jehoash, the son of Ahaziah, at Beth Shemesh. Then he came to Jerusalem and breached the wall of Jerusalem from the Gate of Ephraim to the Corner Gate, four hundred cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took all the gold and silver, all the vessels found in the house of the Lord and in the treasuries of the king’s house, and hostages, and then returned to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds Jehoash did, his power and how he fought with Amaziah king of Judah, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoash slept with his fathers and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. Jeroboam his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah the son of Joash king of Judah lived fifteen years after the death of Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the rest of the deeds of Amaziah, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: They made a conspiracy against him in Jerusalem, and he fled to Lachish. But they sent after him to Lachish, and killed him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They carried him on horses, and he was buried in Jerusalem with his fathers in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Judah took Azariah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king instead of his father Amaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built Elath and restored it to Judah after the king slept with his fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifteenth year of Amaziah the son of Joash, king of Judah, Jeroboam the son of Joash, king of Israel, became king in Samaria for forty-one years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not turn aside from all the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He restored the border of Israel from the entrance of Lebo Hamath to the Sea of the Arabah, according to the word of the Lord God of Israel, which He spoke by His servant Jonah the son of Amittai, the prophet, who was from Gath Hepher.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord saw the very bitter affliction of Israel. There was no one left, imprisoned or free, and no helper for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had not said that He would wipe out the name of Israel from under heaven, so He saved them by the hand of Jeroboam son of Joash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jeroboam, all that he did and his power, how he fought, and how he recovered for Israel Damascus and Hamath, which had belonged to Judah, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam slept with his fathers, with the kings of Israel. Zechariah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-seventh year of Jeroboam king of Israel, Azariah son of Amaziah, king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was sixteen years old when he became king, and he reigned fifty-two years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jekoliah from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the sight of the Lord, according to all that his father Amaziah had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high places were not removed. The people continued sacrificing and making offerings on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord afflicted the king, and he was leprous until the day of his death. He lived in a separate house. Jotham the king’s son was in charge of the house, judging the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Azariah, and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Azariah slept with his fathers, and they buried him with his fathers in the City of David. Jotham his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-eighth year of Azariah king of Judah, Zechariah the son of Jeroboam became king of Israel in Samaria for six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, as his fathers had done. He did not turn aside from the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum the son of Jabesh conspired against him, struck him at Ibleam, and killed him. Then Shallum reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Zechariah are written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the word of the Lord which He spoke to Jehu, “Your sons will sit on the throne of Israel to the fourth generation.” And it was so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum son of Jabesh became king in the thirty-ninth year of Uzziah king of Judah. He reigned for a month in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Menahem son of Gadi went up from Tirzah, entered Samaria, and struck Shallum son of Jabesh in Samaria and killed him. Then Menahem reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Shallum and the conspiracy he made are written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Menahem struck Tiphsah and all who were in it, and the territories around Tirzah. Because they did not open up the city to him, he attacked it. Then he split open all its pregnant woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-ninth year of Azariah king of Judah, Menahem son of Gadi became king over Israel for ten years in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not turn aside all his days from the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pul the king of Assyria came against the land, and Menahem gave Pul a thousand talents of silver, that he might help him strengthen his control of the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Menahem exacted the money from Israel, from all the very wealthy men, fifty shekels of silver each, to give to the king of Assyria. So the king of Assyria left and did not stay there in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the deeds of Menahem, and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: And Menahem slept with his fathers, and Pekahiah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fiftieth year of Azariah king of Judah, Pekahiah the son of Menahem became king over Israel in Samaria for two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not turn aside from the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pekah son of Remaliah, his officer, conspired against him and struck him in Samaria, in the palace of the king’s house, with Argob, Arieh, and fifty men of the Gileadites with him. He killed him and reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Pekahiah and all that he did are written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifty-second year of Azariah king of Judah, Pekah son of Remaliah became king over Israel in Samaria for twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not turn aside from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days of Pekah king of Israel, Tiglath-Pileser king of Assyria came and took Ijon, Abel Beth Maakah, Janoah, Kedesh, Hazor, Gilead, Galilee, and all the land of Naphtali, and then exiled them to Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hoshea son of Elah made a conspiracy against Pekah son of Remaliah and struck and killed him. Then he reigned in his place in the twentieth year of Jotham son of Uzziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the deeds of Pekah and all that he did are written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year of Pekah son of Remaliah, king of Israel, Jotham son of Uzziah, king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jerusha daughter of Zadok.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the sight of the Lord. He did according to all that his father Uzziah had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only he did not remove the high places. The people continued sacrificing and making offerings on the high places. He built the upper gate of the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jotham, and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days the Lord began to send Rezin king of Aram and Pekah son of Remaliah against Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jotham slept with his fathers and was buried with his fathers in the City of David his father. Then Ahaz his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventeenth year of Pekah son of Remaliah, Ahaz son of Jotham, king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz was twenty years old when he became king, and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem. He did not do what was right in the sight of the Lord his God like David his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in the way of the kings of Israel and even made his son pass through the fire according to the abominations of the nations whom the Lord dispossessed before the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sacrificed and made offerings on the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rezin king of Aram and Pekah son of Remaliah, king of Israel, came up to Jerusalem to battle, and they besieged Ahaz but could not subdue him.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Rezin king of Aram recovered Elath for Aram and expelled the Judeans from Elath. The Edomites came to Elath and live there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahaz sent messengers to Tiglath-Pileser king of Assyria, saying, “I am your servant and your son. Come up and save me from the hand of the king of Aram and from the hand of the king of Israel, who are rising up against me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahaz took the silver and gold that was found in the house of the Lord and in the treasures of the king’s house, and sent a present to the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Assyria listened to him. The king of Assyria went up to Damascus, captured it, exiled the people to Kir, and killed Rezin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Ahaz went to Damascus to meet Tiglath-Pileser king of Assyria and saw an altar that was in Damascus. King Ahaz sent to Uriah the priest a pattern of the altar and model of it, according to the manner of its construction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Uriah the priest built an altar according to all that King Ahaz had sent from Damascus. Thus Uriah the priest worked until King Ahaz came from Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king came back from Damascus and saw the altar, the king approached the altar and made offerings on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He offered his burnt offering and his grain offering, poured out his libations, and sprinkled the blood of his peace offerings upon the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the bronze altar that was before the Lord he moved from the front of the house, from between the altar and the house of the Lord. He put it on the north side of the new altar.
speaker: Narrator
