text: Then King Ahaz commanded Uriah the priest, “Upon the great altar offer the morning burnt offering, the evening grain offering, the king’s burnt offering, and his grain offering with the burnt offering of all the people of the land, their grain offering, and their libations. Sprinkle on it all the blood of the burnt offering and all the blood of the sacrifice, and the bronze altar will be for me to inquire by.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Uriah the priest did everything that King Ahaz commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Ahaz cut off the bases of the stands and removed the basin from them. He took down the sea from off the bronze oxen that were under it and put it on stone pavement.
speaker: Narrator

text: The structure for the Sabbath that they had built in the house and the king’s outer entrance he removed from the house of the Lord for the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Ahaz that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz slept with his fathers and was buried with his fathers in the City of David. Then Hezekiah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah, Hoshea son of Elah became king in Samaria over Israel for nine years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, only not as the kings of Israel who were before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against him. Hoshea became his servant and gave him gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Assyria found conspiracy in Hoshea, for he had sent messengers to So king of Egypt and offered up no gift to the king of Assyria as he had done year by year. So the king of Assyria detained him, and then put him in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria went throughout all the land, went up to Samaria, and besieged it for three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the ninth year of Hoshea, the king of Assyria seized Samaria and exiled Israel to Assyria. He put them in Halah, in Habor by the River of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.
speaker: Narrator

text: This happened because the children of Israel had sinned against the Lord their God, who had brought them up from the land of Egypt from under the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt. They had feared other gods
speaker: Narrator

text: and walked in the statutes of the nations, whom the Lord dispossessed before the children of Israel, and walked in the statutes which the kings of Israel had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel ascribed things to the Lord their God that were not so, and they built for themselves high places in all their cities from the watchtower to the fortified city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set up standing stones and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: There they burned incense on all the high places, as the nations did whom the Lord had carried away before them. And they did wicked things to provoke the Lord to anger,
speaker: Narrator

text: for they served idols, of which the Lord had said to them, “You shall not do this thing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord warned Israel and Judah by all the prophets and by all the seers, saying, “Turn from your evil ways, and keep My commandments and My statutes, according to all the law which I commanded your fathers and which I sent to you by My servants the prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they would not listen. They stiffened their necks, like the neck of their fathers, who did not believe in the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They rejected His statutes and His covenant that He had made with their fathers and the decrees He had given them. They followed idols, and became idolaters, and followed the surrounding nations, concerning whom the Lord commanded them, that they should not do like them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They forsook all the commandments of the Lord their God, made themselves cast images (two calves), made an Asherah pole, worshipped all the host of heaven, and served Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: They caused their sons and daughters to pass through the fire, used divination and omens, and sold themselves to do evil in the sight of the Lord to anger Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord was very angry with Israel and removed them from His presence. None remained except the tribe of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah also did not keep the commandments of the Lord their God, but walked in the statutes of Israel which they made.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord rejected all the seed of Israel, afflicted them, and gave them into the hand of plunderers until He had cast them out of His presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He had torn Israel from the house of David, and they made Jeroboam the son of Nebat king. Jeroboam diverted Israel from following the Lord and caused them to sin greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the children of Israel walked in all the sins which Jeroboam committed. They did not turn aside from them
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Lord removed Israel from His presence as He had said by all His servants the prophets. So Israel was exiled from their land to Assyria until this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria brought people from Babylon, Kuthah, Avva, Hamath, and Sepharvaim and put them in the cities of Samaria instead of the children of Israel. They possessed Samaria and lived in its cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right at the beginning of their settling there, they did not fear the Lord, so the Lord sent lions among them, and they killed some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said to the king of Assyria, “The nations which you have exiled and settled in the cities of Samaria do not know the law of the god of the land. Therefore He has sent lions among them; they are killing them, because they do not know the requirements of the god of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria commanded, “Escort back one of the priests whom you exiled from there and let him go and dwell there. Let him teach them the law of the god of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the priests whom they had exiled from Samaria came and lived in Bethel. He taught them how they should fear the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But each nation was making its own gods, and they put them in the houses of the high places that the people of Samaria had made, each nation in the cities where they were living.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Babylon made Sukkoth Benoth, the men of Kuthah made Nergal, the men of Hamath made Ashima,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Avvites made Nibhaz and Tartak. The Sepharvites were burning their children in fire to Adrammelek and Anammelek, the gods of Sepharvaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: They feared the Lord and made from amongst themselves priests of the high places, who were working for them in the houses of the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: They feared the Lord, and they were serving their own gods, after the manner of the nations whom they exiled from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: To this day they continue to practice their former customs. They do not fear the Lord, nor are they doing according to the statutes, requirements, the law or commandment that the Lord commanded the children of Jacob, whom He named Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had made a covenant and commanded them, saying, “You shall not fear other gods, nor bow yourselves to them. You shall not serve them or sacrifice to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, the Lord, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt with great power and an outstretched arm, Him you shall fear, to Him you shall bow down, and to Him you shall sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The statutes, the ordinances, the law, and the commandment, which He wrote for you, you shall observe to do forever. And you shall not fear other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The covenant that I have made with you, you shall not forget. You shall not fear other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather the Lord your God you shall fear, and He will deliver you from the hand of all your enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen; rather they were practicing their former customs.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these nations feared the Lord and were serving their carved images, both their children and their grandchildren, as their fathers did, and so they are doing to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of Hoshea son of Elah, king of Israel, Hezekiah the son of Ahaz, king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Abi daughter of Zechariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the sight of the Lord, according to everything that David his father had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed the high places, broke down the sacred pillars, cut down the Asherah poles, and crushed the bronze serpent that Moses had made, for until those days the children of Israel had made offerings to it. They called it Nehushtan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He trusted in the Lord God of Israel. Afterwards, there was no one like him among all the kings of Judah or among those who were before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He clung to the Lord. He did not depart from following him, but kept His commandments, which the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with him. Wherever he went, he prospered. He rebelled against the king of Assyria and did not serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck the Philistines as far as Gaza and its territory, from watchtower to fortified city.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year of King Hezekiah, which was the seventh year of Hoshea son of Elah, king of Israel, Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against Samaria and besieged it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He seized it at the end of three years. In the sixth year of Hezekiah, that is, the ninth year of Hoshea king of Israel, Samaria was taken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria exiled Israel to Assyria and put them in Halah and in Habor by the River of Gozan and in the cities of the Medes,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they did not obey the voice of the Lord their God, but transgressed His covenant and all that Moses the servant of the Lord commanded, and would not obey or do them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah king of Judah sent word to the king of Assyria at Lachish, saying, “I have done wrong; turn away from me. I will bear whatever you put on me.” So the king of Assyria required of Hezekiah king of Judah three hundred talents of silver and thirty talents of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hezekiah gave him all the silver that was found in the house of the Lord and in the treasuries of the king’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Hezekiah cut off the gold from the doors of the temple of the Lord and from the doorposts that Hezekiah king of Judah had overlaid and gave it to the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria sent the Tartan, the Rabsaris, and the Rabshakeh from Lachish to King Hezekiah with a great army against Jerusalem. So they went up and came to Jerusalem. When they went up, they came and stood by the conduit of the upper pool, which is on the highway of the Fuller’s Field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they called to the king, and Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, Shebna the scribe, and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder, came out to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Rabshakeh said to them, “Speak to Hezekiah:
“Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: What is the basis of your confidence?
speaker: Narrator

text: You speak empty words concerning counsel and strength for the war. Now on whom do you trust, that you have rebelled against me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, look! You trust in the staff of this bruised reed, on Egypt, on which if a man leans, it will enter his hand and pierce it. So is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who trust in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you say to me, ‘We trust in the Lord our God,’ is it not He, whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem, ‘You shall worship before this altar in Jerusalem’?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, make a wager with my lord king of Assyria. I will give you two thousand horses if you are able to set riders on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: How can you turn away one official of the least of my master’s servants and put your trust on Egypt for chariots and horsemen?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have I come up apart from the will of the Lord against this place to destroy it? The Lord said to me, Go up against this land and destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, Shebna, and Joah said to the Rabshakeh, “Speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it. Do not speak with us in the language of Judah in earshot of the people who are on the wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Rabshakeh said to them, “Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you, and not to the men sitting on the wall, who are about to eat their own dung and drink their own urine with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Rabshakeh stood and called with a loud voice in the language of Judah, “Hear the word of the great king, the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the king: ‘Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he is not able to deliver you from my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let Hezekiah make you trust in the Lord, saying, The Lord will surely deliver us, and this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not listen to Hezekiah, for thus says the king of Assyria: ‘Submit to me; come out to me, so that every man may eat from his own vine and his own fig tree and drink water from his own cistern,
speaker: Narrator

text:
until I come and take you to a land like your own land, a land of grain and wine, a land of bread and vineyards, a land of olive oil and honey, that you may live and not die.’
“Do not listen to Hezekiah when he leads you astray saying, The Lord will deliver us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Has any of the gods of the nations at all delivered its land from the hand of the king of Assyria?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah? Have they delivered Samaria from my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who among all the gods of the lands have delivered their land out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem from my hand?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people were silent and answered him not a word, for the king’s command was, “Do not answer him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, Shebna the scribe, and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and entered the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent Eliakim, who was over the household, Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests, covered with sackcloth, to Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Thus says Hezekiah: This day is a day of distress, chastisement, and disgrace, for children have come to the mouth of the womb, but there is no strength to birth them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps the Lord your God will hear all the words of the Rabshakeh, whom the king of Assyria, his master, has sent to taunt the living God and will rebuke the words that the Lord your God has heard, and you might lift up a prayer for the remnant that are left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah said to them, “Thus shall you say to your master, ‘Thus says the Lord: Do not be afraid of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am putting a spirit in him, and he will hear a report and return to his own land. Then I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria warring against Libnah, for he had heard that he had departed from Lachish.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard concerning Tirhakah king of Cush, “He has come out to fight against you,” he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus you shall speak to Hezekiah king of Judah, saying: Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you, saying: Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands by annihilating them. Will you be delivered?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them, the nations that my fathers destroyed, Gozan, Harran, Rezeph, and the sons of Eden who were in Tel Assar?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, of Hena, and Ivvah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it. Then Hezekiah went up to the house of the Lord and spread it before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hezekiah prayed before the Lord and said, “O Lord, God of Israel, who sits on the cherubim, You alone are God over all the kingdoms of the earth. You have made the sky and the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Incline, O Lord, Your ear and hear. Open, O Lord, Your eyes and see. Hear the words of Sennacherib, which he sent to taunt the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Surely, O Lord, the kings of Assyria have annihilated the nations and their lands
speaker: Narrator

text: and have put their gods in the fire, for they were no gods but the work of men’s hands, wood and stone; thus they have been destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, O Lord our God, save us from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You, O Lord, are God alone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent word to Hezekiah, saying, “Thus says the Lord God of Israel: That which you have prayed to Me concerning Sennacherib king of Assyria I have heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the word that the Lord has spoken concerning him:
She despises you, she ridicules you—
    virgin daughter of Zion.
Behind you, she shakes her head—
    daughter of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whom have you taunted and blasphemed?
    And against whom have you raised a voice
and lifted your eyes upward?
    Against the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By your messengers
    you have taunted the Lord,
and have said,
    ‘With my many chariots
I have gone up the height of the mountains,
    to farthest reaches of Lebanon,
and I will cut down its tallest cedars,
    its choicest junipers.
I will enter its most remote canopies of night,
    its dense forest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have dug wells
    and drunk foreign waters,
and I dried up with the sole of my foot
    all the streams of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you not heard?
    Long ago I arranged it,
in ancient times I formed it;
    now I bring it to pass,
that you will turn impregnable cities
    into desolate heaps of stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their inhabitants are powerless;
    they are terrified and ashamed.
They are like grass of the field
    and new vegetation,
grass on the roof tops,
    scorched before it stands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But I know your dwelling place,
    your going out and your coming in,
    and your raging against Me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you have raged against Me,
    and your self-assuredness has come up to My ears,
I will put My hook in your nose
    and My bridle on your lips,
and I will turn you back
    on the way by which you came.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This will be the sign to you:
This year you will eat what grows itself,
    and in the second year the same.
Then in the third year sow, reap,
    and plant vineyards, and eat their fruits.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The spared of the house of Judah who remain
    will again take root below, and bear fruit above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For from Jerusalem a remnant will go forth,
    and escapees from Mount Zion.
“The zeal of the Lord of Hosts will do this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria:
He will not enter this city,
    shoot an arrow there,
approach it with shield,
    or heap up a siege ramp against it.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For I will protect this city to save it,
    for My own sake and for the sake of David My servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that night the angel of the Lord went out and struck one hundred and eighty-five thousand in the camp of the Assyrians. When others woke up early in the morning, these were all dead bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Sennacherib king of Assyria departed and stayed in Nineveh.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was worshipping in the house of Nisrok his god, Adrammelek and Sharezer his sons struck him with the sword, and they escaped into the land of Ararat. Esarhaddon his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Hezekiah became ill and was near death. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came to him, and said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Set your house in order, for you shall die and not live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned his face toward the wall and prayed to the Lord, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please, O Lord, remember how I have walked before You faithfully and with an undivided heart and have done what is good in Your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now before Isaiah had come out of the middle courtyard, the word of the Lord came to him, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Turn back and say to Hezekiah the leader of My people: Thus says the Lord, the God of David your father: I have heard your prayer; I have seen your tears. I will heal you. On the third day you shall go up to the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will add to your days fifteen years, and I will deliver you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria. I will defend this city for My own sake and for the sake of David My servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah said, “Take a cake of figs.” So they took it and laid it on the boil, and he recovered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “What will be the sign that the Lord will heal me, and that I should go up to the house of the Lord on the third day?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah said, “This is the sign to you from the Lord, that the Lord will do the thing that He has spoken: Should the shadow walk forward ten steps or go back ten steps?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah answered, “It is an easy thing for the shadow to stretch ten steps, so let it go back ten steps.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah the prophet called to the Lord, and He made the shadow go back ten steps on the stairs of Ahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Marduk-Baladan son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah, for he had heard that Hezekiah had been ill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah welcomed them and showed them all the treasure house, the silver, the gold, the spices, the fine oil, all the armory, and all that was found in his storehouses. There was nothing in his house nor in all his dominion that Hezekiah did not show them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah and said to him, “What did these men say? From where did they come to you?”
Hezekiah said, “They came from a distant land, from Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “What have they seen in your house?”
Hezekiah said, “They have seen everything in my house. There is nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: The days are coming when everything that is in your house and that your fathers have stored up until this day will be carried off to Babylon. Nothing will be left, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of your sons who go out from you, who will be born to you, will be taken away. They will be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord that you have spoken is good.” And he said, “Why not, if there is peace and security in my days?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the deeds of Hezekiah, all his power, how he made a pool and a conduit and brought water into the city, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah slept with his fathers, and Manasseh his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned fifty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hephzibah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, according to the abominations of the nations whom the Lord dispossessed before the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went back and rebuilt the high places that Hezekiah his father had destroyed. He erected altars for Baal, made an Asherah pole as Ahab king of Israel had done, and worshipped all the host of heaven and served them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built altars in the house of the Lord, of which the Lord had said, “In Jerusalem I will put My name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He built altars for all the host of heaven in the two courts of the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made his son pass through the fire, was conjuring and seeking omens, and dealt with mediums and soothsayers. He did much evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking Him to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put a carved image of Asherah that he had made in the house of which the Lord said to David and to Solomon his son, “In this house and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all tribes of Israel, I will put My name forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not make the feet of Israel to wander homeless from the land that I gave to their fathers, if only they will be careful to do according to all that I have commanded them and according to all the law that My servant Moses commanded them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen. Manasseh led them to do more evil than the nations whom the Lord had destroyed before the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke by His servants the prophets, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Because Manasseh king of Judah has done these abominations, things more evil than all that the Amorites did, and has also caused Judah to sin with his idols,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore thus says the Lord God of Israel: I am bringing evil on Jerusalem and Judah, such evil that the ears of whoever hears about it will tingle.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line of Samaria and the level of the house of Ahab, and I will wipe out Jerusalem as one wipes out a bowl, wiping it and turning it upside down.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will disregard the remnant of My inheritance and give them into the hand of their enemies. They shall become plunder and spoil for all their enemies,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they have done evil in My sight and have provoked Me to anger, since the day their fathers came out of Egypt, even to this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Manasseh shed innocent blood very much, until he had filled Jerusalem from one end to the other; besides his sin he caused Judah to sin by doing evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Manasseh, all that he did, and his sin that he committed, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh slept with his fathers, and was buried in the garden of his house, in the garden of Uzza. Amon his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king. He reigned two years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Meshullemeth, daughter of Haruz of Jotbah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, as his father Manasseh had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in all the ways that his father walked, served the idols that his father served, and worshipped them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He abandoned the Lord God of his fathers, and he did not walk in the way of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The servants of Amon conspired against him and killed the king in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of the land struck all those who conspired against King Amon, and the people of the land made Josiah his son king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Amon that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: And he was buried in his tomb in the garden of Uzza, and Josiah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Josiah was eight years old when he became king, and he reigned thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jedidah daughter of Adaiah from Bozkath.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the sight of the Lord and walked in all the ways of David his father. He did not turn aside to the right hand or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eighteenth year of King Josiah the king sent Shaphan son of Azaliah, son of Meshullam, the scribe, to the house of the Lord, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go up to Hilkiah the high priest, and have him prepare the money that has been brought to the house of the Lord, which the keepers of the threshold have gathered from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them deliver it to the hand of the appointed workers of the house of the Lord, and let them give it to the workers who are in the house of the Lord to repair the damages to the house,
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, to the carpenters, the builders, and the masons to buy timber and cut stone to repair the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there need be no settling of accounts with them concerning the money that was given to their hand, because they are behaving honestly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hilkiah the high priest said to Shaphan the scribe, “I have found the Book of the Law in the house of the Lord.” Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan, and he read it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shaphan the scribe came to the king and brought the king a report. He said, “Your servants have emptied the money that was found in the house and have given it into the hand of the appointed workers of the house of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaphan the scribe informed the king, saying, “Hilkiah the priest has given me a book.” So Shaphan read it before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king had heard the words of the Book of the Law, he tore his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king commanded Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam son of Shaphan, Akbor son of Micaiah, Shaphan the scribe, and Asaiah, a servant of the king, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go, inquire of the Lord for me, for the people, and for all Judah concerning the words of this book that has been found, for great is the wrath of the Lord that is kindled against us, because our fathers have not obeyed the words of this book by doing according to all that is written concerning us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam, Akbor, Shaphan, and Asaiah went to Huldah the prophetess, wife of Shallum, son of Tikvah, son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe (she lived in Jerusalem in the second quarter), and they spoke with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to them, “Thus says the Lord God of Israel: Tell the man that sent you to Me,
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the Lord: See, I will bring evil on this place and on its inhabitants—all the words of the book that the king of Judah has read.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because they have forsaken Me and have made offerings to other gods, so that they have provoked Me to anger with all the works of their hands, therefore My wrath will be kindled against this place, and it will not be quenched.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the king of Judah who sent you to inquire of the Lord, thus shall you say to him, “Thus says the Lord God of Israel with regard to the words you have heard:
speaker: Narrator

text: Because your heart was timid, and you humbled yourself before the Lord when you heard what I spoke against this place and against its inhabitants, that they should become a desolation and a curse, and you have torn your clothes and wept before Me, I also have heard you, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, I will gather you to your fathers, and you will be gathered to your grave in peace. Your eyes will not see all the evil which I am about to bring upon this place.”
Then they brought the king a report.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king sent them away and they gathered all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king went up to the house of the Lord, and all the men of Judah and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem with him, the priests, the prophets, and all the people, both small and great. He read in their hearing all the words of the Book of the Covenant that was found in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king stood by a pillar and made a covenant before the Lord to follow the Lord, to keep His commandments, His testimonies, and His statutes with all his heart and all his soul, to perform the words of this covenant that were written in this book. All the people agreed with the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king commanded Hilkiah the high priest, the priests of the second order, and the keepers of the threshold to bring out of the temple of the Lord all the implements that were made for Baal, for Asherah, and for all the host of heaven. Then he burned them outside Jerusalem in the fields of Kidron and carried their ashes to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he removed the idolatrous priests whom the kings of Judah had ordained to burn incense on the high places at the cities of Judah and around Jerusalem; those also who burned incense to Baal, to the sun, to the moon, to the constellations, and to all the host of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought out the Asherah from the house of the Lord to the outside of Jerusalem, to the Kidron Valley. Then he burned it at the Kidron Valley, crushed it to dust, and threw its dust upon the graves of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He tore down the houses of the male cult prostitutes that were in the house of the Lord, where the women were weaving hangings for the Asherah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought all the priests out of the cities of Judah and defiled the high places where the priests had made offerings, from Geba to Beersheba. He broke down the high places of the gates at the entry of the gates of Joshua the governor of the city, which were on the left at the gate of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: However the priests of the high places did not go up to the altar of the Lord in Jerusalem. Instead they ate unleavened bread among their fellow priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: He defiled Topheth, which is in the Valley of Ben Hinnom, so that no man would make his son or his daughter pass through the fire to Molek.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed the horses that the kings of Judah had given to the sun, at the entry of the house of the Lord, by the hall of Nathan-Melek the eunuch, which was in the vestibule. The chariots of the sun he burned with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The altars that were on the roof of the upper chamber of Ahaz, which the kings of Judah had made, and the altars which Manasseh had made in the two courts of the house of the Lord the king tore down and banished from there and threw their dust into the Kidron Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: The high places east of Jerusalem, south of the Mount of Corruption, which Solomon the king of Israel had built for Ashtoreth the abomination of the Sidonians, for Chemosh the abomination of the Moabites, and for Molek the abomination of the Ammonites, the king defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text: He broke the standing stones, cut down the Asherah poles, and filled their sites with human bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the altar that was at Bethel and the high place which Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who made Israel sin, had made, both that altar and the high place he tore down. Then he burned the high place and crushed it to powder, and he burned the Asherah.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Josiah turned, he saw the tombs that were there on the mount. He took the bones out of the tombs and burned them on the altar and defiled it, according to the word of the Lord that the man of God proclaimed, the one who announced these things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said, “What is this monument that I see?”
The men of the city said to him, “It is the tomb of the man of God who came from Judah and proclaimed these things that you have done against the altar of Bethel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Let him rest. No one shall disturb his bones.” So they let his bones alone, with the bones of the prophet who came out of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, all the houses of the high places that were in the cities of Samaria, which the kings of Israel had made to provoke the Lord to anger, Josiah removed. He did to them just as he had done in Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He slaughtered on the altars all the priests of the high places who were there, and burned human bones on them. Then he returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king commanded all the people, “Keep the Passover to the Lord your God as it is written in this Book of the Covenant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For such a Passover had not been kept from the days of the judges who judged Israel, nor in all the days of the kings of Israel and the kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the eighteenth year of King Josiah, this Passover was kept to the Lord in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Josiah disposed of the mediums, the soothsayers, the teraphim, the idols, and all the abominations that were seen in the land of Judah and in Jerusalem, so that he established the words of the law that were written in the book that Hilkiah the priest found in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there had been no king like him before or after, who turned to the Lord with all his heart, with all his soul, and with all his might, according to all the Law of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the Lord did not turn from the fierceness of His great wrath, by which His anger was kindled against Judah, because of all the provocations with which Manasseh had provoked Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “I will also remove Judah from before Me, as I have removed Israel. I will reject this city that I have chosen, Jerusalem, and the house of which I said, My name shall be there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Josiah, and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: In his days Pharaoh Necho, king of Egypt, went up against the king of Assyria to the River Euphrates. King Josiah went to meet him, but he killed him at Megiddo when he had seen him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants carried him dead in a chariot from Megiddo, brought him to Jerusalem, and buried him in his own tomb. The people of the land took Jehoahaz the son of Josiah, anointed him, and made him king in place of his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he became king, and he reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that his fathers had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh Necho imprisoned him at Riblah in the land of Hamath, so that he might not reign in Jerusalem, and imposed tribute on the land of a hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh Necho made Eliakim son of Josiah king in place of Josiah his father and changed his name to Jehoiakim. He took Jehoahaz away and went to Egypt, and he died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiakim gave the silver and gold to Pharaoh, but he taxed the land to give the money according to Pharaoh’s demand. According to an assessed amount, he exacted the silver and gold from the people of the land to give to Pharaoh Necho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he became king. He reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zebidah daughter of Pedaiah of Rumah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that his fathers had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his days Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up, and Jehoiakim became his servant for three years. Then he turned and rebelled against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent against him bands of Chaldeans, bands of Arameans, bands of Moabites, and bands of Ammonites. He sent them against Judah to destroy it, according to the word of the Lord that He spoke by His servants the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely at the decree of the Lord this came upon Judah, to remove them from before Him, for the sins of Manasseh, according to all that he had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: and also for the innocent blood that he had shed, for he filled Jerusalem with innocent blood, and the Lord was not willing to pardon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jehoiakim and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoiakim slept with his fathers, and Jehoiachin his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Egypt did not come again from his land, for the king of Babylon had taken over from the Brook of Egypt to the River Euphrates all that belonged to the king of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he became king. He reigned in Jerusalem three months. His mother’s name was Nehushta daughter of Elnathan of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that his father had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the servants of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up against Jerusalem, and the city was under siege.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up to the city while his servants were besieging it,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jehoiachin king of Judah went out to the king of Babylon, he, his mother, his servants, his princes, and his eunuchs. The king of Babylon took him in the eighth year of his reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought out from there all the treasures of the house of the Lord and the treasures of the king’s house, and cut in pieces all the implements of gold in the temple of the Lord, which Solomon king of Israel had made, just as the Lord had spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: He exiled all Jerusalem, all the princes, and all the mighty men of valor, ten thousand captives, and all the craftsmen and smiths. No one remained, except the poorest people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He exiled Jehoiachin in Babylon. The king’s mother, the king’s wives, his eunuchs, and the elite of the land he took into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the fighting men, seven thousand, the craftsmen and smiths, one thousand, all those strong and fit for war the king of Babylon brought them into exile in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon made Mattaniah, the uncle of Jehoiachin, king in his place and changed his name to Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king. He reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that Jehoiakim had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of the anger of the Lord this happened in Jerusalem and Judah until He threw them out from His presence. But Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came, he and all his army, against Jerusalem, and set up camp near it. They built siege mounds against it all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city came under siege until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the ninth day of the fourth month the famine was severe in the city, and there was no food for the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city was breached, and all the fighting men fled by night by the way of the gate between the two walls, which is by the king’s garden, though the Chaldeans were all around the city. They went along the way of the Arabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the army of the Chaldeans pursued the king and overtook him in the plains of Jericho. All his army deserted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they captured the king and brought him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah, and they passed sentence upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They slaughtered the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes, and put out the eyes of Zedekiah. They bound him with bronze fetters and brought him to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth month, on the seventh day of the month (that was the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon), Nebuzaradan, the captain of the bodyguard, a servant of the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He burned the house of the Lord, the king’s house, and all the houses of Jerusalem. Every great house he burned with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the army of the Chaldeans who were with the captain of the guard tore down the walls of Jerusalem all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the people who remained in the city, the deserters who had defected to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the crowd Nebuzaradan the captain of the bodyguard took into exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the captain of the bodyguard left some of the poor of the land to be vinedressers and farmers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bronze pillars that were in the house of the Lord, the stands, and the bronze sea that were in the house of the Lord the Chaldeans broke in pieces, and carried their bronze to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pots, the shovels, the snuffers, the incense bowls, and all the bronze implements which were used in service they took away.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fire pans and sprinkling basins that were fine gold and fine silver the captain of the bodyguard took.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two pillars, the one sea, and the stands, which Solomon had made for the house of the Lord—the bronze of all these implements was beyond weight.
speaker: Narrator

text: The height of the one pillar was eighteen cubits, and a bronze capital was on it. The height of the capital was three cubits. Latticework and pomegranates, all of bronze, were on the capital all around. The second pillar with its latticework was like it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the bodyguard took Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the second priest, and the three keepers of the threshold.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the city he took a eunuch who was an officer over the fighting men, five men of the king’s council who were found in the city, the chief scribe of the army who mustered the people of the land, and sixty men from the people of the land who were found in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuzaradan captain of the bodyguard took them, and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king of Babylon struck them down and killed them at Riblah in the land of Hamath.
Thus he exiled Judah from their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Over the people who remained in the land of Judah, whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had left, he appointed Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the captains of the armies, they and their men, heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah, they came to Gedaliah at Mizpah, that is, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan son of Kareah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth the Netophathite, and Jaazaniah son of the Maakathite, they and their men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gedaliah swore to them and to their men, and said to them, “Do not be afraid of being the servants of the Chaldeans. Live in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it will go well for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the seventh month, Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, the son of Elishama, of the royal line, came with ten men and struck down Gedaliah. He died along with the Judeans and Chaldeans who were with him at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people, both small and great, and the captains of the armies arose and went to Egypt, for they were afraid of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin king of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, Awel-Marduk king of Babylon, in the year that he became king, released Jehoiachin king of Judah from prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spoke kindly to him, and gave him a throne above the thrones of the kings that were with him in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: He changed his prison garments, and he ate food continually before him all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: His allowance was a regular allowance given him by the king every day, all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator
